title: Independent Study Project (ISP) Collection
author: Authors
cleaned_text: The ISP, or Independent Study Project, is written by students from the [undergraduate programs of SIT Study Abroad](http://www.sit.edu/studyabroad.htm) and relates to a program theme. Using primary sources students choose topics with a manageable focus that can be carried out in a variety of settings, such as schools, nongovernmental organizations or field research stations. During the independent study period students work closely with a project advisor and other key contacts in the field. The ISP is typically a 20- to 40-page paper presented to student colleagues, the academic director and, often, the advisor and other interested host-country individuals. Copyright permissions have been obtained by all contributors to this collection. Submissions from 2018 [FROM ORGAN TO GAMELAN: JAVANESE CATHOLIC MUSICAL TRADITIONS IN YOGYAKARTA, CENTRAL JAVA](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2939), Elizabeth Hamilton, University of Denver [The UN's Political Engagement in the Occupied Palestinian Territories: Reconceptualized Strategies in Humanitarianism and Diplomacy in the Middle East Peace Process](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2808), Alara Hanci, Tufts University [Andean condor nesting and behavior: A study of a free-living pair and chick as well as population behavior near Antisana Ecological Reserve, Ecuador](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2924), The Case of Relmu Ñamku as an observatory to assess the potentials, risks, and challenges of intercultural jury trials](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2770), Carol Harding, Bates College [Poem as Space for Artistic Contestation: Finding Multiple Voices of Female Writers through Artistic Vocabularies](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2999), Edil Hassan, University of Vermont [Church and State in Rwanda: Catholic Missiology and the 1994 Genocide Against the Tutsi](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2830), Marcus Timothy Haworth, University of Notre Dame [Religion and Identity in a Globalized Morocco](https://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/2837), Jennifer Morgan Hekking, Hobart & William Smith Colleges ["If you seek, you know you will find and if you find you have cancer, why do you seek?"
